abstract: High cost of advertising in early primary states has caused major super PACs to abandon expensive television spots they have relied on in past in favor of field operations, research and voter registration efforts; turn to on-the-ground effort is among most significant changes in outside political spending since Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United decision, but outcome of such action remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: The groups, conceived as a way to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money on television, are now overseeing nuts-and-bolts jobs like field operations and data collection.

byline.original: By NICK CORASANITI and MATT FLEGENHEIMER
byline.contributor: Nicholas Confessore contributed reporting from New York.

headline.main: As TV Ad Rates Soar, ‘Super PACs’ Pivot to Core Campaign Work
headline.print_headline: ‘Super PACs’ Now Hit Road, Not Airwaves

snippet: The groups, conceived as a way to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money on television, are now overseeing nuts-and-bolts jobs like field operations and data collection....
